nodes.bodyText: There seems to be a transitive data visibility dependency from _state to _version, so to ensure _version is well defined this should be a memory_order_acquire load.
Is RPCTarget::isValid() ever used in a way where the caller assumes something about the contents of _version based on the return value here? If so, consider using memory_order_acquire here as well.

By removing the check for _state == VERSION_RESOLVED, doesn't this open up for the following race condition?

Thread reads _state == TARGET_INVOKED cached into local state variable, attempts to enter critical section. Is put on hold by kernel.
MBus thread receives resolved version, enters critical section, finishes processing handlers and finally sets _state = VERSION_RESOLVED
Original thread wakes up, enters critical section
Original thread sees that cached state value is not equal to PROCESSING_HANDLERS, does not enter branch that can set hasVersion = true
Original thread initiates new version fetch towards peer even though version has already been resolved
New round of same race condition possible by any other subsequent concurrent senders

Note that it should be safe to use the original expression with both loads being made explicitly relaxed, as visibility should be guaranteed from entering the critical section. That should avoid the race condition while not introducing any memory fences.

commit.message: Use original logic to avoid race condition.
